description.narrative: To provide Jordan with the tools to achieve effective compliance with respect its Convention obligations and the objective of substantively minimizing the environmental and health risks.

activity-description.narrative: Implementation of phase I of a Comprehensive polychlorinated biphenyl (PCB) management system in Hashemite Kingdom of Jordan

description.narrative: Component 1 Laws regulations and guidelines for PCB management developed Component 2 Sustained and targeted awareness raising on various levels

Information dissemination
campaigns ensure availability of
printed and electronic information
through workshops and work with
media

comment.narrative:
Significant gaps in knowledge
about PCB associated risks
ï No information products
published
ï Very limited number of
workshops held

Information products developed
and published
ï National workshops are
arranged throughout the
projects duration to distribute
developed information packages
ï Media coverage on PCB issues
is ensured

The PCBs project has produced a documentary movie demonstrating the activities of the project and the successful disposal of pure PCBs as well as contaminated equipment and associated material oils extracted contaminated concretesoil at spillage sites used PPEs The video was filmed in May 2015 and is in CD usable format which is planned by the project team to be uploaded on Youtube
The PCBs project success story was published as part of a global UNDP POPs publication which was distributed to delegates during COP7 in Geneva May 2015
A PCB event took place on 30 August 2014 with the objective to sign the Basel Notification by PCBs waste holders CEGCO Lafarge JPMC and JoPetrol The event was under the patronage of the Minister of Environment and was also covered by media see links in Media section page 2
One PAC meeting was held just before the reporting period started April 2014 through related to the onward set of activities related to discussion of contaminated oil replacement and required arrangements

Information products developed
and published
ï National workshops are
arranged throughout the
projects duration to distribute
developed information packages
ï Media coverage on PCB issues
is ensured

The PCBs project has produced a documentary movie demonstrating the activities of the project and the successful disposal of pure PCBs as well as contaminated equipment and associated material oils extracted contaminated concretesoil at spillage sites used PPEs The video was filmed in May 2015 and is in CD usable format which is planned by the project team to be uploaded on Youtube
The PCBs project success story was published as part of a global UNDP POPs publication which was distributed to delegates during COP7 in Geneva May 2015
A PCB event took place on 30 August 2014 with the objective to sign the Basel Notification by PCBs waste holders CEGCO Lafarge JPMC and JoPetrol The event was under the patronage of the Minister of Environment and was also covered by media see links in Media section page 2
One PAC meeting was held just before the reporting period started April 2014 through related to the onward set of activities related to discussion of contaminated oil replacement and required arrangements

description.narrative: Development of PCB detection and analytical capacity through equipment tools and specialized training for analytical surveys Development of ESM system and specialized training for PCB experts to promote the systems applicability in practice Identification and setup of storage facilities for proper interim PCB containment

ï Country has a comprehensive
inventory of PCB containing
and contaminated equipment
ï Reports from personnel
responsible for equipment
testing
ï Labeling of tested equipment
showing the new
classifications PCBs free
contaminated above 50 ppm
ï 2 units of portable sampling
and testing equipment are
supplied
ï 2 engineers per utility company
are trained in the use of such
equipment

comment.narrative:
Analytical capacity is limited
to specialized labs with GC
equipment lacks modern
protocols for PCB
identification and skills for the
use of such protocols GC
equipment is expensive per
unitary sample test and slow in
delivering testing results
ï Country does not have a
comprehensive inventory of
PCB equipment

ï All potentially contaminated oil
transformers at utility sector and
major private industries are
tested for PCB Equipment is
labeled and registered
ï Comprehensive PCB equipment
inventory is done and helps
accurate reporting to the
authorities
ï PCB equipment is recorded in a
centralized manner for the use
by authorities and for public
information
ï The database serves reporting
obligations to the Stockholm
Convention
ï Analytical capacity is upgraded
through the supply of portable
equipment and GC protocols
and specialized trainings for
existing labs

To ensure sustaining the functionality of the database and to ensure newly purchased electrical equipment can be tested five 5 previous PCB analytical devices type Dexil L2000 were distributed to five 5 PCB holding companies as following
1 JEPCO company in Zarqa governorate
2 IDECO in Irbid governorate
3 NEPCO in Amman
4 EDCO in Tafilah governorate
5 EDCO in Aqaba
All these devices were officially transferred to companies property
A 6th device will stay in the MoEnv for reference purposes as the Ministry continues to fulfill its monitoring role
All samples from equipment suspected to be PCB contaminated after analysis by L2000 were sent for GC analysis by local accredited lab for confirmation
GC analysis indicated that 82 samples out of 14062 were contaminated with PCBs 5 of them having contamination levels above 1000 ppm
Only eight 8 pieces of this PCB crosscontaminated equipment will be kept online from private sector and National Water Authority until they reach end of useful life and then be disposed of by companies means by 2025
The rest of 74 pieces of transformers will be drained with shutdown time of 34 hours in the ongoing second disposal contract with SITA Five 5 emptied transformers 61 tons and 485 tons of contaminated oil will be exported for final disposal
These transformers which will be drained and the light contaminated oil will be replaced with new mineral oil old utility method to reduce contamination levels down to below 50 ppm SC limits will be tested again after 6 months for their new contamination levels by the assigned ITC with another mission
The second tender is the result of a previous market study mentioned that was conducted by project to assess the costs of rental or purchase of PCB decontamination technology Sea Marconi or Bilger the costs of rent are more than double the direct disposal of such oils

transformers at utility sector and
major private industries are
tested for PCB Equipment is

To ensure sustaining the functionality of the database and to ensure newly purchased electrical equipment can be tested five 5 previous PCB analytical devices type Dexil L2000 were distributed to five 5 PCB holding companies as following
1 JEPCO company in Zarqa governorate
2 IDECO in Irbid governorate
3 NEPCO in Amman
4 EDCO in Tafilah governorate
5 EDCO in Aqaba
All these devices were officially transferred to companies property
A 6th device will stay in the MoEnv for reference purposes as the Ministry continues to fulfill its monitoring role
All samples from equipment suspected to be PCB contaminated after analysis by L2000 were sent for GC analysis by local accredited lab for confirmation
GC analysis indicated that 82 samples out of 14062 were contaminated with PCBs 5 of them having contamination levels above 1000 ppm
Only eight 8 pieces of this PCB crosscontaminated equipment will be kept online from private sector and National Water Authority until they reach end of useful life and then be disposed of by companies means by 2025
The rest of 74 pieces of transformers will be drained with shutdown time of 34 hours in the ongoing second disposal contract with SITA Five 5 emptied transformers 61 tons and 485 tons of contaminated oil will be exported for final disposal
These transformers which will be drained and the light contaminated oil will be replaced with new mineral oil old utility method to reduce contamination levels down to below 50 ppm SC limits will be tested again after 6 months for their new contamination levels by the assigned ITC with another mission
The second tender is the result of a previous market study mentioned that was conducted by project to assess the costs of rental or purchase of PCB decontamination technology Sea Marconi or Bilger the costs of rent are more than double the direct disposal of such oils

description.narrative:
Three interim PCB accumulation
and storage points are installed
and meet internationally accepted
standards for safety and
management by 2012

comment.narrative:
Lack of modern and safe
interim PCB accumulation and
storage points
ï Owners of PCB transformers
willing to dispose of the
priority hazardous materials in
poor condition lack the
opportunity to do so
ï Unprotected storages for
disconnected electrical
equipment including PCB
equipment increase the risks of PCB spread into the environment

Three PCB accumulation and
storage facilities are upgraded to
meet internationally accepted
standards and this backstops the
functioning of the ESM system
ï All phased out transformers
especially those that are tested
for PCB above 50 ppm PCB
capacitors and other PCB
materials are stored in safe and
environmentally sound manner
which meets internationally
gtUncontrolled PCB releases from
stored disconnected PCB
equipment are minimized

A JEPCO managed PCB oil draining facility site in Zarqa has already been established and has been upgraded to meet internationally benchmarked standards It is capable of temporarily storing PCN materials JEPCO also plans to complete its separate longerterm PCB storage facility which will accept drummed oil emptied transformers and capacitors if found in future
Up until this reporting period the IDECO storage site has still not been constructed due to internal management changes and obstacles inside IDECO
In summary three facilities are expected to be available in the country EDCO as planned originally will not participate in the project

Three PCB accumulation and
storage facilities are upgraded to
meet internationally accepted
standards and this backstops the
functioning of the ESM system
ï All phased out transformers
especially those that are tested
for PCB above 50 ppm PCB
capacitors and other PCB
materials are stored in safe and
environmentally sound manner
which meets internationally
gtUncontrolled PCB releases from
stored disconnected PCB
equipment are minimized

A JEPCO managed PCB oil draining facility site in Zarqa has already been established and has been upgraded to meet internationally benchmarked standards It is capable of temporarily storing PCN materials JEPCO also plans to complete its separate longerterm PCB storage facility which will accept drummed oil emptied transformers and capacitors if found in future
Up until this reporting period the IDECO storage site has still not been constructed due to internal management changes and obstacles inside IDECO
In summary three facilities are expected to be available in the country EDCO as planned originally will not participate in the project

description.narrative:
Development of ESM system is
completed and its successful
implementation is backstopped by
appropriate PCB legislative
framework

comment.narrative:
ï PCB equipment handling is
unsafe and does not meet any
international norms
ï Potentially PCB contaminated
equipment goes for metal
scrapping
ï Low level awareness of PCB
associated risks
ï No specialized training in safe
PCB management has been
provided and no capacity
exists to prevent PCB releases
or equipment crosscontamination
ï No secure PCB material
storage facilities exist

ï ESM system is developed
ï PCB holders are aware of PCB
risks associated with equipment
maintenance and retirement
ï Private sector is trained in
identification and registration of
PCB equipment
ï Three regional PCB storage
facilities established and
upgraded to meet international
standards with appropriate
training for personnel
ï Private sector is provided
professional services to pickup
transport and handle indentified
PCB materials in ESM manner
to prepare

Based on PCB inventory purposes after the first tender for disposal was complete only crosscontaminated transformer equipment was detected and JEPCO IDECO EDCO JoPertol Lafarge and JPMC have shown their willingness to dispose of contaminated oil
They are committed to project activities and have provided all necessary equipment and tools for the draining of contaminated PCB oil
Of the found 82 crosscontaminated transformers 8 will be retained in use for a number of years before they reach the end of useful lifetime and 74 transformers will be drained with oil replaced with new mineral oil This will amount to 485 tons of contaminated oil being removed from Jordan and disposed in an environmentally sound way
One 1 transformer maintenance and PCB oil draining facility was established by JEPCO in Zarga Governorate and one 1 more dedicated storage facility for PCB equipment materials is under construction by same utility company IDECO company based on limited inventory found at its grid network decided to construct its future storage facility in another location with correspondingly less space
Despite being outside of the reporting period and taken place midMarch 2014 the project had supported a special training of the Ministry of Environment Task Force team which will continue with PCBs issues after project closure Twenty 20 staff members of the Ministry of Environment and its directorates were trained in ESMPCB management system
This group is intended to help the project team in the verification of inventory results and will ensure the implementation of PCB instructions after the completion of the project the training covered the sampling registration of information into database labeling and analysis of oil water and soil samples

ï ESM system is developed
ï PCB holders are aware of PCB
risks associated with equipment
maintenance and retirement
ï Private sector is trained in
identification and registration of
PCB equipment
ï Three regional PCB storage
facilities established and
upgraded to meet international
standards with appropriate
training for personnel
ï Private sector is provided
professional services to pickup
transport and handle indentified
PCB materials in ESM manner
to prepare

Based on PCB inventory purposes after the first tender for disposal was complete only crosscontaminated transformer equipment was detected and JEPCO IDECO EDCO JoPertol Lafarge and JPMC have shown their willingness to dispose of contaminated oil
They are committed to project activities and have provided all necessary equipment and tools for the draining of contaminated PCB oil
Of the found 82 crosscontaminated transformers 8 will be retained in use for a number of years before they reach the end of useful lifetime and 74 transformers will be drained with oil replaced with new mineral oil This will amount to 485 tons of contaminated oil being removed from Jordan and disposed in an environmentally sound way
One 1 transformer maintenance and PCB oil draining facility was established by JEPCO in Zarga Governorate and one 1 more dedicated storage facility for PCB equipment materials is under construction by same utility company IDECO company based on limited inventory found at its grid network decided to construct its future storage facility in another location with correspondingly less space
Despite being outside of the reporting period and taken place midMarch 2014 the project had supported a special training of the Ministry of Environment Task Force team which will continue with PCBs issues after project closure Twenty 20 staff members of the Ministry of Environment and its directorates were trained in ESMPCB management system
This group is intended to help the project team in the verification of inventory results and will ensure the implementation of PCB instructions after the completion of the project the training covered the sampling registration of information into database labeling and analysis of oil water and soil samples

description.narrative: Development of capacity to securely transport handle package securely stockpile PCB wastes and disposal of stockpiles pure and contaminated

Incoming inventory reports
from the interim storages on
quantities characteristics and
origin of the PCB materials
ï Trained personnel at the
storage sites to assist in
transporting the waste material
to storagehandling sites safe
PCB oil draining packing and
securing the wastes by 2012
ï Additional tests for crosscontaminated
equipment which
underwent oil replacement
equipment contamination
level allowed at 1000 ppm
upper limit level
ï Disposal of 40 tons of pure and
100 tons of contaminated PCB
materials by export to a
licensed disposal facility by
2014

comment.narrative:
Limited capability in the safe
handling of PCB materials
ï PCB equipment is sent for
scrap and contamination of
media and exposure of
workers continues

ï National capacity to handle
PCB materials for final safe
disposal is improved
ï Economical solution for oil
transformers with contamination
below 1000 ppm PCB in the oil
is developed
ï Equipment containing PCB 40
tons and oil contaminated with
PCB above 50 ppm 100 tons
will be disposed of according to
international standards and
practices for all times
ï Number of PCB contaminated
transformers is reduced in the
country allowing minimizing
further equipment crosscontamination

As part of the first tender from 1226 October 2014 the projects international technical consultant ITC and one expert from Tredi the disposal company conducted a training for 6 local staff of CEGCO and 4 engineers from other electrical companies on the draining of PCB oil from Askarel transformers packaging labeling and use of required PPE equipment and tools as well as safety precautions measures Trained engineers subsequently trained additional staff
CEGCO staff AL Hussein Power Plant under the direct supervision of the ITC and Tredi completed the draining and packaging of 47 tons of PCB Askarel equipment
The emptied transformers capacitors and drummed oil were loaded up into two 20foot and one 40foot containers stored outside the main building of the Al Hussein Power Plant in the protected industrial area for 4 months until Basel notification approval was received
The PCB waste was shipped on the 7th of March 2015 and arrived at the disposal facility in France on 27 March 2015 The MoEnv and UNDP project received the disposal certificate on 27 May 2015 for full first batch
As for the current second tender which selected SITA for export of the original estimate of 50 tons of lightly crosscontaminated oil inclusive of 45 tons of oil and 2 emptied transformers the PCB project team provided all PCBs owners with a list of required equipment tools and PPEs for the draining activities Companies purchased PPE using their own resources
Currently it is being discussed to add 3 more scrap transformers to the existing bid by an upward contract revision for SITA and the second disposal contract will hence include 485 tons of crosscontaminated oil and 61 tons of empty transformer carcasses the final target of the second tender being 546 tons
Prior to the draining of contaminated oil the project team verified the companies readiness via field visits And the draining process was supervised by the ITC in three different locations
One engineer from each company attended the training for Askarel draining held in October 2014 Then they trained their own staff
The ITC provided the project management with a technical report to describe and evaluate the draining process with recommendations for improvements for the further draining process in sites where it was not yet complete as of June 2015 mission

ï National capacity to handle
PCB materials for final safe
disposal is improved
ï Economical solution for oil
transformers with contamination
below 1000 ppm PCB in the oil
is developed
ï Equipment containing PCB 40
tons and oil contaminated with
PCB above 50 ppm 100 tons
will be disposed of according to
international standards and
practices for all times
ï Number of PCB contaminated
transformers is reduced in the
country allowing minimizing
further equipment crosscontamination

As part of the first tender from 1226 October 2014 the projects international technical consultant ITC and one expert from Tredi the disposal company conducted a training for 6 local staff of CEGCO and 4 engineers from other electrical companies on the draining of PCB oil from Askarel transformers packaging labeling and use of required PPE equipment and tools as well as safety precautions measures Trained engineers subsequently trained additional staff
CEGCO staff AL Hussein Power Plant under the direct supervision of the ITC and Tredi completed the draining and packaging of 47 tons of PCB Askarel equipment
The emptied transformers capacitors and drummed oil were loaded up into two 20foot and one 40foot containers stored outside the main building of the Al Hussein Power Plant in the protected industrial area for 4 months until Basel notification approval was received
The PCB waste was shipped on the 7th of March 2015 and arrived at the disposal facility in France on 27 March 2015 The MoEnv and UNDP project received the disposal certificate on 27 May 2015 for full first batch
As for the current second tender which selected SITA for export of the original estimate of 50 tons of lightly crosscontaminated oil inclusive of 45 tons of oil and 2 emptied transformers the PCB project team provided all PCBs owners with a list of required equipment tools and PPEs for the draining activities Companies purchased PPE using their own resources
Currently it is being discussed to add 3 more scrap transformers to the existing bid by an upward contract revision for SITA and the second disposal contract will hence include 485 tons of crosscontaminated oil and 61 tons of empty transformer carcasses the final target of the second tender being 546 tons
Prior to the draining of contaminated oil the project team verified the companies readiness via field visits And the draining process was supervised by the ITC in three different locations
One engineer from each company attended the training for Askarel draining held in October 2014 Then they trained their own staff
The ITC provided the project management with a technical report to describe and evaluate the draining process with recommendations for improvements for the further draining process in sites where it was not yet complete as of June 2015 mission

description.narrative: Implementation of a comprehensive PCBs management system in the Hashemite Kingdom of Jordan

Comprehensive PCB management
system is installed on countrywide
level through capacity
building which is tested and
promoted by demonstration for
PCB final disposal in order to
meet Jordans obligation under the
Stockholm Convention by the end
of the project

comment.narrative: Lack of uptodate regulatory measures for PCB control

Regulatory measures to assist in
the identification labelling
capturing and disposing of PCB
materials

PCBs instructions Management of PCB and PCB contaminated materials to manage all issues related to PCBs including but not limited to export import registration analysis storage and treatment were approved and published during the previous reporting period Prime ministerial endorsement of the Instruction on PCB Management adopted under the Article 4D of Environmental Law 562006 dated March 2 2014 in Gazette no 5273
Stakeholder involvement has been generally good but certain stakeholder groups including the Inspection Directorate Monitoring Directorate and Customs Authority are not yet familiar with the new regulation and this was included as a recommendation in currently developed terminal evaluation report for the project to attempt to achieve during the remaining 6 months implementation time

Regulatory measures to assist in
the identification labelling
capturing and disposing of PCB
materials

PCBs instructions Management of PCB and PCB contaminated materials to manage all issues related to PCBs including but not limited to export import registration analysis storage and treatment were approved and published during the previous reporting period Prime ministerial endorsement of the Instruction on PCB Management adopted under the Article 4D of Environmental Law 562006 dated March 2 2014 in Gazette no 5273
Stakeholder involvement has been generally good but certain stakeholder groups including the Inspection Directorate Monitoring Directorate and Customs Authority are not yet familiar with the new regulation and this was included as a recommendation in currently developed terminal evaluation report for the project to attempt to achieve during the remaining 6 months implementation time

description.narrative: Project results are evaluated used in adaptive management and replicated

ME and adaptive management
applied to project in response to
needs midterm evaluation
findings with lessons learned
extracted

comment.narrative:
ï No Monitoring and Evaluation
system
ï No evaluation of project
output and outcomes

ï Monitoring and Evaluation
system developed during year 1
ï Midtermevaluation of project
output and outcomes conducted
with lessons learnt at 30 months
of implementation
ï Final evaluation report ready in
the end of project

MTEs recommendations exercise held in 2013 were followed in the remaining projects implementation time such as projects extension to allow for completion of storage site constructions GC checks for suspected contamination after portable L2000 was used and detected chlorine presence etc
Project work plan and budget for the year 2015 were approved
The projects management ensured appropriate stakeholder participation and involvement in the projects implementation including coordinating the work of all stakeholders through project board meetings email communications phone calls and field visits to company sites
Extension for 9 months was granted to enable the project team to complete the additional tender for contaminated oil disposal
It is anticipated that the disposal of this last task to be concluded by March next year 2016

ï Monitoring and Evaluation
system developed during year 1
ï Midtermevaluation of project
output and outcomes conducted
with lessons learnt at 30 months
of implementation
ï Final evaluation report ready in
the end of project

MTEs recommendations exercise held in 2013 were followed in the remaining projects implementation time such as projects extension to allow for completion of storage site constructions GC checks for suspected contamination after portable L2000 was used and detected chlorine presence etc
Project work plan and budget for the year 2015 were approved
The projects management ensured appropriate stakeholder participation and involvement in the projects implementation including coordinating the work of all stakeholders through project board meetings email communications phone calls and field visits to company sites
Extension for 9 months was granted to enable the project team to complete the additional tender for contaminated oil disposal
It is anticipated that the disposal of this last task to be concluded by March next year 2016
